drinkName.name: Hebridean Shores
drinkName.about: The Finnieston in Glasgow, tabbed as a gin bar in a Gin & Tonic town, puts Bruichladdich The Classic Laddie scotch to use in this light, fruity drink, topped with a floater of IPA.

ingredients.ingredient: BrewDog Elvis Juice IPA, to float

mix.how: Add all the ingredients except for the beer into a shaker with ice and shake.
Fine-strain into a Collins glass over ice.
Top with the beer.
Garnish with a grapefruit slice.

drinkName.name: Dramble
drinkName.about: In this riff on the Bramble, the honeyed fruits and floral notes of Dewar’s 12-year-old scotch play well with the Briottet crème de mûre liqueur while taking the drink in an entirely different direction.

mix.how: Combine the scotch, lemon juice and syrup in a shaker with ice, and shake.
Fine-strain into a hurricane glass over crushed ice, and drizzle with the liqueur.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Campbeltown
drinkName.about: This scotch drink at Edinburgh’s Bramble Bar routinely shows up on lists of the world’s best cocktail bars. It interweaves the fruity sweetness and tart of Cherry Heering liqueur with the strong herbal notes of Green Chartreuse and has a backbone of Springbank 10-year-old-scotch, a well-balanced whisky with enough depth and richness to stand up to both.

mix.how: Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.
Strain into a Nick & Nora glass, express the oil of a lemon peel, and discard the peel.

drinkName.name: Let’s Pumpkin
drinkName.about: Perfect for a Halloween or fall party, this pumpkin punch includes a six-spice syrup and little meringue tops.

mix.how: Serves 8 to 12.
With a jagged edge, cut open the top of a pumpkin, scoop out the seeds, and rinse out the pumpkin.
Add all of the ingredients into the pumpkin with ice and stir.
Add 5 lemon wheels, thinly sliced, and 3 pineapple wheels, thinly sliced, to the bowl for garnish.
Serve in a mini hollowed-out harvest pumpkin or glass mug, top with Marshmallow Fluff or meringue that’s then toasted with a hand torch, and garnish with a cinnamon stick.

*Fall spice syrup: Toast 2 tsp of cardamom in a saucepan at medium heat. Add 5 whole star anise, 1 tsp of nutmeg, 5 diced stems of whole ginger root, 3 cinnamon sticks, 3 cloves, 1 whole orange twist, 2 cups of fine white sugar and 2 cups of water, and stir until the sugar has completely dissolved. Let it cool for 30 minutes, and use a fine-mesh sieve to strain into a Mason jar. (Keeps in the refrigerator for up to 4 weeks.).

**Toasted meringue: Separate 5 whole eggs and place the whites in a large bowl. Beat the egg whites with an electric or handheld mixer until they become soft. Add 3 tsp of sugar gradually as the egg whites are beaten to stiff peaks. Use a large spoon to transfer the meringue into a plastic-coated pastry bag to squeeze the meringue onto each punch-filled glass mug or mini pumpkin.

drinkName.name: Sour T-iesel
drinkName.about: This CBD hemp oil and tequila cocktail by Jason Eisner at Gracias Madre is oh-so-California.

ingredients.ingredient: Organic cold-pressed CBD oil (extracted from industrial hemp)

mix.how: Place all of the ingredients except for the CBD oil and aquafaba in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake vigorously.
Fine-strain into a 64 oz container, and add the CBD oil and aquafaba. Emulsify the liquid for 5 seconds with a handheld emulsifier on turbo.
Transfer the liquid back into the cocktail shaker, and strain the liquid into a coupe glass with a Hawthorne strainer.
To create a pot leaf image atop the cocktail, use a stencil and ceremonial-grade matcha.
Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and roll back and forth from the mixing glass to another one.
Strain into a highball glass with ice, and garnish with a lemon wedge and celery stalk.
Add the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until cold.
Strain into a Martini glass, and garnish with lemon zest.

drinkName.name: Butternut Squash Old Fashioned
drinkName.about: The orange flesh of butternut squash has a natural sweetness to it, which gets sweeter still when roasted with a bit of maple syrup, making it an ideal veg to infuse into robust bourbon in the fall.

mix.how: In a mixing glass, combine all of the ingredients with ice and stir.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh cracked ice, and garnish with an orange peel.

*Squash-infused bourbon: Cut 2 cups of butternut squash into chunks. Add the squash, 1/4 cup of maple syrup and 1 tsp of cinnamon. Spread the squash on a baking sheet and bake in the oven at 350 degrees for 15 minutes or until soft. Allow to cool. In a large Mason jar, combine the squash with 1 750mL bottle of bourbon (like Buffalo Trace), and set the empty bottle aside until later. Cover tightly and allow it to infuse for two to three weeks. Strain the bourbon, funnel back into the empty bottle (be sure to label the bottle), and cap tightly. The infused bourbon should keep for five to seven days.

drinkName.name: X-Mas Sin
drinkName.about: OK, sure, the name of this cocktail has a naughty Christmas sort of vibe. But that doesn’t mean you can’t sip this steamy drink all throughout the colder months, enjoying the pick-me-up hint of coffee paired with the rich bite of Armagnac.

ingredients.ingredient: Château de Laubade XO Bas Armagnac

mix.how: In a small saucepan, combine all of the ingredients except for the water, and heat without bringing to a boil.
Strain the mixture into a toddy glass, and top with hot water to fill.

drinkName.name: Folle Blanche Crusta
drinkName.about: Blanc Armagnac is a relative newcomer to the scene and has only been officially recognized by the Armagnac powers-that-be for a handful of years. Its youth in a world of grand dames, though, means it serves as a fine introduction to the spirit for those not quite ready to take the VSOP plunge. This fruity play on a traditional Brandy Crusta is a drink for every season and palate.

ingredients.ingredient: Château du Tariquet Folle Blanche Armagnac

mix.how: Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake.
Strain into a rocks glass with ice, and garnish with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Magic Cotton Candy Daiquiri
drinkName.about: This cocktail is pure boozy magic. Watch the fluff of sugar disappear before your very eyes!

mix.how: Place a big fluff of cotton candy in the cocktail glass.
Add rum and lime juice to a shaker and fill with ice.
Shake, then strain into the glass, dissolving the cotton candy.
Top with Champagne. Garnish with a lime wheel.

drinkName.name: Adonis
drinkName.about: Give this easy-drinking, low-alcohol sipper a spin. Made with equal parts sherry and vermouth, it pairs beautifully with tapas and other savory bites.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.
Pour into a coupe glass, and garnish with an orange peel.

drinkName.name: Corpse Reviver No. Blue
drinkName.about: Bacardí brand ambassador Jacob Briars created this drink as a joke, but it’s become a popular order, so he gets the last laugh. It is similar to the Corpse Reviver No. 2, but swaps Cointreau for blue curaçao.

mix.how: Rinse a chilled coupe or Martini glass with absinthe and set aside.
Add the remaining ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.
Fine-strain into the prepared glass, and garnish with a lemon peel.

drinkName.name: Surfer on Acid
drinkName.about: Created by Eric Tecosky in the 1990s, this popular cocktail can be made as a shot. But you can civilize this Jägermeister cocktail a bit by serving it on the rocks (or even straight up in a cocktail glass).

mix.how: Place the sugar into a rocks glass. Add the bitters and 1 oz of the scotch before filling the glass with ice.
Slowly stir, gradually adding the remaining scotch until the sugar has dissolved and the mixture is chilled.
Garnish with a twist of fresh orange zest and a cherry.
Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice and stir well.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass, and garnish with lemon zest and a cherry.
Muddle fresh ginger in a shaker, and add the remaining ingredients except for the Craigellachie 13.
Fill the shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.
Double-strain into an ice-filled rocks glass, and float the Craigellachie on top.
Garnish with a piece of candied ginger.

drinkName.name: Bourbon Sweet Tea
drinkName.about: Make a batch for your next party. Or just spend the weekend sitting on the porch, rocking your cares away.

ingredients.ingredient: Crushed ice, plus more for serving

mix.how: Combine the boiling water and sugar in a heatproof container. Stir until sugar is dissolved.
Add the tea bags and steep for 5 minutes. Remove tea bags and discard.
Pour the tea base into a heatproof pitcher or serving jar. Add the cold water, ice and bourbon. Stir well, and refrigerate until serving.
To serve, pour into an ice-filled highball glass or Old Fashioned glass.
Garnish with mint and lemon slices.

drinkName.name: Alaska
drinkName.about: This gin cocktail, made with Yellow Chartreuse and orange bitters, “dances between spirit-driven and citrus-forward,” according to Keli Rivers of San Francisco’s Whitechapel. “It’s good, moving from one side of the spectrum to the other.”

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass, express the oil of a lemon peel over the drink, and garnish with that lemon peel.

drinkName.name: Saturn
drinkName.about: This gin-based Tiki cocktail “carries the regality of a Mai Tai with the drinkability of a Tom Collins,” according to Garret Richard of New York City’s Slowly Shirley and The Happiest Hour.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to a blender with crushed ice, and blend until smooth.
Pour unstrained into a Tiki mug or highball glass.
Garnish with a parasol, edible flower and orange peel.
Serve with a straw.
*Passion fruit syrup: Mix 6 parts simple syrup to 1 part passion fruit purée.

drinkName.name: Jack Rose
drinkName.about: This classic cocktail from the 1920s and ’30s takes its name from its main ingredient of applejack and the resulting color from grenadine.

ingredients.ingredient: Freshly squeezed lime or lemon juice

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, and shake until chilled.
Fine-strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a lime or lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Coronation Cocktail No. 1
drinkName.about: This classic sherry cocktail recipe hails from Harry Craddock’s 1930 book, The Savoy Cocktail Book<.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice, and stir for 30 seconds.
Fine-strain into a coupe glass, and garnish with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Seelbach
drinkName.about: The glittering mixture of local bourbon, orange liqueur, two kinds of bitters, and Champagne is the signature drink of Louisville’s Seelbach Hotel. Once thought to be a classic rediscovered in the ’90s after decades of obscurity, the drink’s inventor recently confessed to having fabricated the vintage backstory. Regardless, the elegant sip is sure to be delighting guests (and faraway strangers) for years to come.

ingredients.ingredient:
Bourbon
Try it with Jefferson\\\'s Kentucky Straight

mix.how: Stir together bourbon, Cointreau and bitters in an ice-filled mixing glass.
Strain into a chilled Champagne flute.
Top with cold Champagne or sparkling wine, and garnish with twist.

drinkName.name: Bramble
drinkName.about: Famed bartender Dick Bradsell invented this classic at Fred’s Club in London’s Soho in the ’80s, inspired by the fresh blackberries he used to get as a child on the Isle of Wight.

mix.how: Add the gin, lemon juice and simple syrup into a shaker with ice and shake.
Fine-strain into an Old Fashioned glass over crushed ice.
Lace over top with the creme de mure.
Garnish with a lemon half-wheel and a fresh blackberry.

drinkName.name: Tommy’s Margarita
drinkName.about: This classic tequila cocktail was created by Julio Bermejo in the early ’90s at Tommy’s Mexican Restaurant in San Francisco where it’s still offered.

mix.how: Prepare a rocks glass with a salt rim.
All all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.
Fine-strain over ice into a rocks glass.

drinkName.name: Bamboo
drinkName.about: Sherry cocktails are getting a lot of love from the bartender community, and this underrated 19th-century drink is a delicious way to go.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with cracked ice, and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe, and garnish with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Mezcal Mule
drinkName.about: Try this smoky variation of the gingery refresher, the Moscow Mule, by Jim Meehan of New York City’s PDT.

mix.how: Add the lime juice and cucumber slices to a mixing glass and muddle.
Add the rest of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.
Stain into a rocks glass filled with ice.
Garnish with a cucumber slice and a piece of candied ginger and top with a pinch of ground chile.

drinkName.name: 20th Century
drinkName.about: All aboard for this legendary gin libation!

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake until chilled for about 15 seconds.
Fine-strain into a chilled coupe, and top with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Old Cuban
drinkName.about: Bartender Audrey Saunders is best known for her work at Soho’s Pegu Club, where her drink credits include this Mojito-meets–French 75 classic.

mix.how: Muddle the lime juice, syrup and mint in a mixing glass.
Add the rum, bitters and ice and shake.
Double-strain into a coupe glass, and top with the Champagne.

drinkName.name: Gin-Gin Mule
drinkName.about: This gingery cocktail found in “New York Cocktails” (Cider Mill Press, $19.95) by Amanda Schuster was created by Audrey Saunders for NYC’s Pegu Club as a gateway gin drink for vodka lovers. Not only did it succeed, it inspired many variations around the world.

mix.how: In a mixing tin, muddle the simple syrup, lime juice and 1 mint sprig.
Add the gin, ginger beer and ice, and shake well.
Strain into a highball glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with 1 mint sprig, and serve with a straw.

drinkName.name: Game Day Sangria
drinkName.about: Made with white wine and hard apple cider, it’s the perfect football party cocktail.

ingredients.ingredient: Unfiltered apple cider or apple juice

mix.how: Mix all of the ingredients together in a punch bowl or iced tea jug.
Serve over ice with sliced fruit as garnish.

drinkName.name: Brancamenta Frappe
drinkName.about: Mint liqueur, mocha gelato and a whole lotta love go into this frozen drink from New Orleans’ Erin Rose.

mix.how: Blend the Brancamenta, gelato and milk in a blender until smooth.
Serve in a 12 oz plastic cup, and top with coffee.

drinkName.name: Daiquiri No. 6
drinkName.about: This twist on the New Orleans favorite goes down easy.

mix.how: Prepare an Old Fashioned glass with a rim of smoked salt.
Blend all of the ingredients in a blender with 1 cup of cracked ice until smooth, and pour into the Old Fashioned glass.

drinkName.name: Brown Bag Daiquiri
drinkName.about: Mezcal is the smoky secret to this hopped-up Daiquiri twist from New Orleans’ Balise.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.
Fine-strain into a coupe wrapped in a piece of a brown bag held together with a spear, and garnish with a lime wedge.

drinkName.name: Deadbeat Daiquiri
drinkName.about: We got the recipe for this modern classic from Beachbum Berry’s Latitude 29 in New Orleans.

ingredients.ingredient: Caña Brava 7-year-old grand reserve añeja rum

mix.how: Blend all of the ingredients in a blender with 1.5 cups crushed ice for up to 20 seconds until frappéd.
Pour unstrained into a Cocktail Kingdom Pearl Diver glass, and garnish with an edible orchid, pineapple wedge and straw.

drinkName.name: El Crepúsculo de Nicaragua (Nicaraguan Twilight)
drinkName.about: Violet liqueur gives this pineapple Daiquiri twist from New Orleans’ Carousel Bar & Lounge an indigo glow.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients and 1 lime wedge into a shaker with ice and shake.
Fine-strain into a chilled Martini glass, and garnish with a lime wedge.

drinkName.name: Good Ships / Wood Ships
drinkName.about: Aged rum gets a kiss of grapefruit and herbal liqueurs in this Daiquiri twist from New Orleans’ Seaworthy.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.
Fine-strain into a coupe, and garnish with a speared grapefruit peel.

drinkName.name: Italian Cookie
drinkName.about: This Daiquiri twist from New Orleans’ Three Muses ain’t your nonna’s creamy nightcap.

mix.how: Blend all of the ingredients with ice in a blender.
Pour into a highball glass, and garnish with Italian sprinkles (jimmies) and a straw.

drinkName.name: Stone & Co.
drinkName.about: Gin and cucumber get a Daiquiri twist from The Mayhaw at St. Roch Market.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to a blender, and blend until smooth.
Garnish with a cucumber wheel.

*Plum syrup: Chop 12 plums, removing seeds. Add 12 cups of water and 12 cups of sugar to a pot. Once the sugar dissolves, add the plums and bring to a boil. After it reaches a boil, turn the heat down and let it simmer, for approximately 2 hours, until the plums are soft. Strain out the plums and transfer to a bottle with a second strain.
**Cucumber syrup: Follow the same steps as the plum syrup but using 8 cucumbers instead.

drinkName.name: Viking Vacation
drinkName.about: Swap out the rum in this Daiquiri twist from New Orleans’ Vessel.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake.
Double-strain into a coupe, and garnish with a lime wheel.

drinkName.name: Torrents of Summer
drinkName.about: If you like a good Daiquiri, try this gingery upgrade from New Orleans’ Kingfish.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.
Fine-strain into coupe, and garnish with a speared lime peel and cherry.

drinkName.name: Rum Cannonball
drinkName.about: Tea-infused booze makes this frozen Daiquiri from New Orleans’ Catahoula Upstairs Bar deluxe.

mix.how: Blend all of the ingredients in a blender with 1.5 cups of crushed ice.
Serve in a hurricane glass, and garnish with an orchid and straw.
*Butterfly pea flower tea liqueur: Mix 2 parts Cane Run rum, 1 part honey, 1 part hot green tea and 1 tbsp pea flower powder.

drinkName.name: Snapsvisa Sour
drinkName.about: Aquavit gives this Daiquiri-inspired sip from New Orleans’ Josephine Estelle a Scandinavian accent.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake.
Fine-strain into a coupe, and garnish with a thyme sprig.

drinkName.name: Jasmine
drinkName.about: This underrated gin cocktail is perfect if you’re looking for something refreshing, citrusy and not too sweet. It also works well with other spirits besides gin.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients into a shaker with ice, and shake to chill.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Mezcal Negroni
drinkName.about: This underrated mezcal cocktail takes a classic Negroni and adds the smoke of mezcal.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to an Old Fashioned glass and fill with ice.
Stir until cold and garnish with an orange half-wheel.

drinkName.name: Ressikan Flute
drinkName.about: This pear brandy cocktail is a nod to the Star Trek episode “The Inner Light.” In it, Captain Picard loses consciousness for 20 short minutes but winds up experiencing decades of a double life in his altered state on the planet of Kataan, a dying planet with water issues, in the village of Ressik. In this new reality, he’s known as a flute-playing family man named Kamin.

ingredients.ingredient: Mas Peyre Le Démon de Midi Rancio Sec (or similar rancio sec)

mix.how: Combine all of the ingredients in a coupe and serve.

drinkName.name: Where No Man Has Gone Before
drinkName.about: This Star Trek–inspired brandy cocktail uses a bunch of ingredients that might make a cocktail aficionado turn up a nose. And honestly, this recipe from Paul Gustings of Broussard’s in New Orleans might be a joke. (It wasn’t exactly delicious when we tested it.)

mix.how: Prepare the instant vanilla pudding, and combine all of the ingredients with the pudding, minus the water, in a mug.
Add the hot water, stir until the instant pudding is dissolved, and serve warm.

drinkName.name: Stovokor
drinkName.about: Bartender Alexandra Kuechler-Caffal is pretty devoted to her love of all-things Trekkie. She created this Star Trek–inspired rum cocktail to show her intergalactic love.

mix.how: Stir all of the ingredients, and serve in a chilled coupe.
Garnish with a port-soaked prune.

drinkName.name: Captain’s Holiday
drinkName.about: It’s a seriously stressful job to sit in the captain’s chair (and wear those tight pants, too) on Star Trek’s Enterprise—be it Pike, Kirk, Picard, Sisco, Janeway, Archer or any of the others who’ve helmed that position, briefly or not. So here’s a much-deserved absinthe and Chartreuse sipper for an otherworldly vacation from the deck.

mix.how: Blend the absinthe, Chartreuse, juices, Bénédictine and Angostura in a blender with ice on high for 7 seconds or until slushy.
Add 4 dashes of Peychaud's bitters, and swirl with a straw until pretty.
Garnish with a paper umbrella.

drinkName.name: Prime Directive
drinkName.about: It’s the guiding principle for all members of Star Trek’s Starfleet: Don’t mess with other civilizations and sully up their worlds. Which is a pretty good rule to follow for drinks, too. Keep things light and herby with this gin cocktail.

mix.how: Stir all of the ingredients, and strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Guinan’s Negroni
drinkName.about: As El-Aurians, Star Trek: The Next Generation’s Guinan and her people are known for their talent as great listeners—just like those people who make nice things for you behind the stick. Inspired by that notion is this sprightly Negroni riff.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients into a mixing glass along with 1 2-inch-by-1-inch piece of lemon peel, and stir over ice.
Serve over a large piece of ice in a double rocks glass.
If you want an extra spacey touch, garnish with 3 cornflowers, express with an additional lemon peel, and serve.

drinkName.name: Pearl Harbor
drinkName.about: This melon pineapple inspired drink is easy to make for those warm Summer days.

mix.how: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake.
Strain into the Old Fashioned glass.
Garnish with Maraschino cherry and pineapple slice.

drinkName.name: Ghost Captain
drinkName.about: This cocktail is inspired by the classic Jack Rose cocktail (apple brandy, lime, grenadine) and uses Amaro di Angostura instead of brandy. The bracing drink, named for a character in pirate legends (Angostura is from Trinidad, hence the name), is all about the balance of the spice and bitterness of amaro, vibrant lime and the sweet-tart grenadine.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice, shake vigorously, and strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish with a lime wedge and serve.

drinkName.name: Suzie Americano
drinkName.about: For this white version of the classic Americano, bartender Tristan Willey mixes Suze, a gentian-based herbal apéritif from Switzerland, with Carpano Bianco, a lightly sweet, round white Italian vermouth. The resulting drink is fragrant and low-alcohol, perfect for day drinking.

mix.how: Add the Suze and Carpano Bianco to a Collins glass filled with ice and stir.
Top with soda water, and garnish with a grapefruit twist.

drinkName.name: Ranye West
drinkName.about: For this slightly bitter and super refreshing drink, bartender Jeff Steiner uses Rainier beer (named for Seattle’s Mt. Rainier), which is a lager-style brew, but feel free to swap it out for your favorite lager.

mix.how: Fill a wine glass with ice, add all of the ingredients and stir.
Garnish with a lemon peel, and serve.

drinkName.name: Ruby
drinkName.about: “The Ruby is a fruit-centric drink,” says bartender Tony Abou-Ganim. “I use a vodka with a good structure, rich mouthfeel and diverse fruit flavors. A potato-based vodka is ideal to help soften and moderate the drink’s bitter and floral elements.”

ingredients.ingredient: Freshly squeezed ruby red grapefruit juice

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass, and shake with ice until well-mixed and the egg white is emulsified.
Strain into a chilled coupe, and garnish with the oils of a grapefruit twist.

drinkName.name: Caesar
drinkName.about: The Canadian answer to the Bloody Mary, this vodka cocktail originally hails from the Calgary Inn, where it may be the only cocktail recipe inspired by a pasta dish.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass, add ice, and roll the contents between mixing glass and a shaker tin until well-blended.
Rim the lip of a double Old Fashioned glass with lime, and dip it into a mixture of the pepper and salt.
Strain into a prepared ice-filled double Old Fashioned glass, and garnish with a carrot sliced lengthwise.

drinkName.name: Caipiroska
drinkName.about: Similar to Brazil’s famed Caipirinha but made with vodka in place of cachaça, this fresh, citrusy drink matches best with “a clean, neutral vodka with fruity, floral notes—something made from corn, wheat or mixed grain, something gentle,” according to bartender Tony Abou-Ganim.

ingredients.ingredient: Simple syrup (or 1 tbsp granulated white sugar)

mix.how: Fill an Old Fashioned glass with cracked ice to chill.
In a mixing glass, add the simple syrup (or sugar) and lime quarters.
Muddle to extract the juice without forcing the rind from the lime.
Dump the ice from the glass into the mixing glass, add the vodka, and shake.
Pour the entire drink with the ice into the chilled glass, and garnish with 4 lime quarters.

drinkName.name: Cocoa À Trois
drinkName.about: This dessert-y sipper has rich, chocolaty underpinnings, so “the drink will pair best with a New-World corn-based or wheat-based vodka rich in vanilla or cocoa elements,” according to bartender Tony Abou-Ganim.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass, and shake vigorously until blended (long enough to dissolve the cocoa powder).
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass, and dust with the grated chocolate.

drinkName.name: Vodka Soda
drinkName.about: This super easy vodka cocktail is popular with those trying to cut calories.

mix.how: In a Collins glass, add the vodka, fill with ice, top with the club soda, and add a squeeze of lemon.
Garnish with a lemon wedge.

drinkName.name: Lillet on the Rocks
drinkName.about: Every home bar should have a bottle of Lillet Blanc. And a glass of Lillet on the rocks makes for a perfect afternoon.

mix.how: In a rocks glass, add the Lillet Blanc and fill with ice.
Garnish with a speared orange peel.

drinkName.name: Beermosa
drinkName.about: This version of a Brass Monkey, made famous by the Beastie Boys, uses a chilled glass and cold beer, instead of a warm 40-ounce bottle.

mix.how: Fill a chilled beer glass with the lager, and top with the orange juice.
Garnish with an orange wheel.

drinkName.name: Vodka Tonic
drinkName.about: This classic vodka cocktail couldn’t be easier to make.

mix.how: In a Collins glass, add the vodka, fill with ice, top with the tonic water, and add a squeeze of lemon.
Garnish with a lemon peel.
Add all of the ingredients into a pilsner glass, add crushed ice, and swizzle with a swizzle stick.
Top with more crushed ice, and pour grenadine on top.
Garnish with a dehydrated lemon wheel and tarragon sprig.

drinkName.name: 50/50 Martini
drinkName.about: This cocktail is made with equal proportions of spirit and vermouth. Some swear by gin in their 50/50s, but it’s great with vodka, because it doesn’t compete with the subtle aromatics of the vermouth.

mix.how: Stir with ice, and strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Pickled-Tomato Blue-Cheese Martini
drinkName.about: A Blue-Cheese–Olive Martini is a steakhouse classic that’s arguably more appetizer than cocktail. This modification uses pickled green tomatoes and Atsby Amberthorn vermouth, an herb-forward vermouth that works especially well in a savory Martini.

ingredients.ingredient: Froehlich's Martini Pickled Tomatoes, for garnish
Rogue Creamery Caveman blue cheese, for garnish

mix.how: Stir the vodka and vermouth with ice, and strain into a picnic glass.
Slice the Martini pickle lengthwise, stuff with the blue cheese, skewer the pickles with a toothpick, and balance on the rim of the glass.

drinkName.name: Prince Edward Martini
drinkName.about: This Vodka Martini is a variation typically made with gin and Atholl Brose, a Speyside single-malt scotch liqueur made with honey and herbs.

mix.how: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled Martini glass.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

drinkName.name: Summer Bummer
drinkName.about: Moscow’s Delicatessen, led by Vyacheslav Lankin, turns out old classics with new twists and brings surprising new ingredients into the mix, like this vodka cocktail made with beetroot shrub.

mix.how: Combine the vodka, orange juice and apple juice in a mixing tin and stir.
Top with the beetroot shrub and absinthe.
Pour all of the ingredients into a shaker, add ice, and shake briefly. Strain and serve over crushed ice in a double Old Fashioned glass.
Garnish with a single fresh rose petal, and mist rose water over top for aromatics.

drinkName.name: ¡A Huevo!
drinkName.about: This mashup of a Michelada and Margarita is a big ¡a huevo! (or “hell, yeah”). Tequila gets a sweetening assist from Bud Light Lime-A-Rita, fresh lime juice pushes the acid forward, and hot sauce (I’m a Valentina guy, but follow your heart) leaves a gentle burn on the end.

mix.how: Salt the rim of a rocks glass.
Add the tequila and lime juice and hot sauce to a shaker with plenty of ice, and shake vigorously for 30 seconds.
Strain into the prepared glass, and top with Bud Light Lime-A-Rita.

drinkName.name: Bodega Dog
drinkName.about: The classic cocktail of gin and grapefruit is called a Greyhound. Add a salt rim, and it’s a Salty Dog. Mess it up with grapefruit beer and spicy seasoning salt, and you get a Bodega Dog.

mix.how: Rim a highball glass with the Tajín, and fill with ice.
Pour in the gin or vodka, and top with the Schofferhofer.

drinkName.name: Sanka, Ya Dead?
drinkName.about: This variation on a Guinness Punch has ice cream stepping in for condensed milk and a splash of Appleton Estate rum for extra hair on the chest. It’s dedicated to fictional Olympic bobsledder Sanka Coffie.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients in a blender, and blend until smooth.
Serve in a chilled pilsner glass.

drinkName.name: High School Friends
drinkName.about: This drink a tart and boozy riff on a Whiskey Sour. The sweet-sourness of Mike’s Hard Lemonade plus the alcoholic bite of Jim Beam bourbon is heaven in a cup.

mix.how: Fill a Julep cup with crushed ice, add the Jim Beam, and stir for 30 seconds.
Add the Mike’s Hard Lemonade, and top off with more crushed ice.

drinkName.name: Big Red
drinkName.about: The snap of ginger, the smoke of scotch, the King of Beers. These are odd but happy bedfellows in this cocktail.

ingredients.ingredient: Johnnie Walker Red Label Scotch whiskey

mix.how: Pour all of the ingredients in a Collins glass filled with ice.

drinkName.name: Vladimiry
drinkName.about: If you’re getting tired of the same old Bloody Mary recipe, it’s time to meet her distant cousin from the East, the Vladimiry.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients except the sprigs and pickles, to a blender, and blend until smooth.
Pour into a highball glass, fill with ice, and stir lightly.
Garnish with a pickle spear and 2 sprigs of dill.

drinkName.name: Joan Collins
drinkName.about: This drink is delicately pink and 100 percent spa day, which is exactly how I imagine the life and times of Joan Collins.

mix.how: In a cocktail shaker, muddle the lime, cucumber and mint.
Add the syrup and vodka with plenty of ice, and shake until chilled.
Strain over ice into a Collins glass, and top with soda water. Serve with a cucumber wheel for garnish.
*Honey-hibiscus syrup: Bring 1/2 cup of honey and 1/2 cup of water to simmer, stirring to incorporate.
Remove from heat, add 1 hibiscus tea bag, and let cool.
Remove the tea bag and store in the refrigerator for up to a month.

drinkName.name: Summer Fridays
drinkName.about: The coconut, key lime and cilantro in this vodka cocktail can immediately send you somewhere warm and sunny with sparkling waters.

mix.how: Add all of the ingredients to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice, and shake until chilled.
Strain into a chilled rocks glass, and garnish with 2 sprigs of cilantro.

drinkName.name: Harry Potter Butterbeer
drinkName.about: No need for a trip to the Three Broomsticks! Harry Potter’s favorite boozy beverage is easy to make at home. Grown-up wizards and adult muggles can make this famously boozy Diagon Alley treat right in their own cauldron. (No spells required.)

mix.how: Combine all of the ingredients in a frosty mug.
Top with a generous dollop of butterscotch whipped cream.

drinkName.name: BACARDÍ® 8 Old Fashioned
drinkName.about: Created in New York in the early 1900s, the iconic Old Fashioned is deemed “the original cocktail.” But even the most established classics can do with a refresh every now and then. Try it with Bacardí 8 Años rum instead of whiskey and call yourself a visionary.

mix.how: Add the sugar, water and bitters with a barspoon into an Old Fashioned glass.
Add half of the rum and 2-3 large ice cubes, stirring repeatedly.
Pour in the second half of the rum and 2-3 more ice cubes, continuing to stir.
Express the oil of an orange peel over the drink, and drop in the peel.
Combine all of the ingredients and shake with ice.
Double-strain into a coupe glass.

ingredients.ingredient: BACARDÍ GRAN RESERVA MAESTRO DE RON®
Club soda or sparkling water, to top

mix.how: Pour the rum, lemon juice and sugar into a cocktail shaker with ice, and give it a good shake.
Fine-strain the mixture into a serving glass, and top it up with the club soda or sparkling water.
Garnish with a lemon peel.

drinkName.name: Traditional Old Fashioned
drinkName.about: So popular they named a glass after it, this whiskey cocktail is a classic go-to.

mix.how: Fill a mixing glass with ice, and add all of the ingredients.
Stir until chilled and diluted, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass with fresh ice.
Garnish with an expressed orange peel and 2 cherries.

drinkName.name: Templeton Manhattan
drinkName.about: This cocktail is the ultimate three-ingredient classic.

mix.how: Fill a cocktail shaker half full with ice, add all of the ingredients, and stir until well chilled and diluted.
Garnish with a cherry.
Serve in a coupe.

drinkName.name: Iowa Buck
drinkName.about: This version of a Buck, or cocktail using ginger beer, uses rye whiskey.

mix.how: Fill a Tom Collins glass with ice, add the whiskey, top with ginger beer and add a squeeze lime.
Garnish with a lime wedge.

drinkName.name: Boulevardier
drinkName.about: This classic three-ingredient cocktail is the rye whiskey version of a Negroni.

mix.how: Fill a mixing glass with ice, add all of the ingredients, and stir until diluted and chilled for about 30 stirs.
Strain and serve up or on the rocks in an Old Fashioned glass.
Garnish with an expressed orange peel.

drinkName.name: Pepin
drinkName.about: This rum cocktail by Emil Åreng of Umeå, Sweden’s Open/Closed was created for the Bacardi Legacy competition.

ingredients.ingredient: Ear of microplaned dried sweetened corn, for garnish

mix.how: Shake all of the ingredients, strain, and top with the corn foam.
*Corn foam: Make 8 cups of simple syrup, add two pre-boiled corn cobs, and let it rest at medium heat for about 1 hour. Strain and add two leaves of gelatin.
Pour into a cream siphon, and add 2 cream chargers.
Let it sit in the fridge for 1 hour.

drinkName.name: Mamie Taylor
drinkName.about: Use a blended scotch that’s not too mild, such as Compass Box Great King Street or The Famous Grouse Smoky Black, in this cocktail from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails.

ingredients.ingredient: Blended scotch (Compass Box Great King Street or The Famous Grouse Smoky Black)
Spicy ginger ale or ginger beer, as a topper

mix.how: Add the scotch and lime juice to a highball glass full of ice, top with the ginger ale, and stir briefly.
Garnish with a lime wedge.

drinkName.name: Monte Carlo
drinkName.about: Opt for a high-proof rye, such as Rittenhouse 100-proof, in this variation on the classic Manhattan from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails.

mix.how: Fill a mixing glass 2/3 full of ice, and add the ingredients.
Stir for about 30 seconds, until well chilled, and strain into a chilled rocks glass.

drinkName.name: Toronto
drinkName.about: In this cocktail from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails, Canadian whisky tames the bitter, herbal bite of Fernet-Branca.

mix.how: Fill a mixing glass 2/3 full of ice, and add the rye, Fernet-Branca, simple syrup and bitters.
Stir for 15 seconds, until chilled and diluted, strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with an orange peel.

drinkName.name: Godfather
drinkName.about: This 1970s-era drink, named for the popular film The Godfather, is often made with equal parts, but this version from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails dials down the sweetness.

mix.how: Fill a mixing glass 2/3 full of ice, add the ingredients, and stir until chilled.
Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

drinkName.name: Godfather
drinkName.about: This 1970s-era drink, named for the popular film The Godfather, is often made with equal parts, but this version from Whiskey: A Spirited Story with 75 Classic & Original Cocktails dials down the sweetness.

mix.how: Fill a mixing glass 2/3 full of ice, add the ingredients, and stir until chilled.
Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.

drinkName.name: Hwayo Negroni
drinkName.about: This riff on the Negroni is made with jasmine-infused soju, Korea’s white spirit usually distilled from rice or sweet potatoes.

ingredients.ingredient: Fee Brothers West Indian orange bitters

mix.how: Stir all ingredients with ice, strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, and garnish with an orange peel.
*Jasmine Hwayo: Pour 1 cup of hot water over 8 grams of jasmine tea leaves.
After five minutes, discard the tea, reserving the “washed” tea leaves.
Steep the tea leaves in 1 cup of Hwayo Soju 41 for 25 minutes, fine-strain, and discard the leaves.
Strain a second time through cheesecloth to catch any remaining particles.
Makes enough jasmine-infused soju for several drinks.

drinkName.name: Demi Peche
drinkName.about: This take on a Shandy is the French version of the classic Radler.

mix.how: Combine the beer and syrup in a pilsner glass and enjoy.
*Demi Peche syrup: Peel, pit and slice 4 ripe peaches and lightly salt with a pinch of kosher salt.
Heat in a saucepan over medium high heat, allowing the peaches to lightly caramelize.
Add 2 cups of refined sugar and 2 cups of water and stir.
Bring to a simmer, stirring frequently, for 2 minutes, remove from heat, and allow to cool to room temperature.
Strain (preferably through a cheesecloth) and refrigerate.

drinkName.name: Professor
drinkName.about: This Shandy served at San Francisco’s Homeroom is ideal for those completely green to mixing cocktails who want something light for summer.

mix.how: Combine the kölsch and limeade in a Mason jar and enjoy.

drinkName.name: Stone’s Shandy
drinkName.about: Ruby-red-infused vodka makes this Shandy served at Stone’s Throw in Houston a spirit-driven delight, while the peach bitters add a soothing dose of juiciness to round out the drink’s flavor profile.

mix.how: Combine all of the ingredients, except for the beer, in a cocktail tin and shake.
Strain into a pint glass, and top with the beer.

drinkName.name: Coppa Shandy
drinkName.about: This version of a Shandy served at Boston’s Coppa has the added one-two punch of both Yellow and Green Chartreuse, creating an herbal depth to the drink that plays nicely with lager.

mix.how: Combine all of the ingredients, except for the beer, in a mixing glass and stir.
Strain over fresh ice in a tall beer mug (or pilsner glass), and top with beer.

drinkName.name: Crimson King
drinkName.about: This drink takes the subtle flavors in a Boulevardier and adds dark cherry and bitter roasted coffee liqueur. Spicy Rittenhouse rye and Campari bring balance for a deep and complex cocktail.

mix.how: Add all of ingredients into a mixing glass with ice.
Stir and strain into a Nick & Nora glass or serve in a rocks glass with a large hunk of ice.
Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

drinkName.name: Jungle Bird
drinkName.about: This classic Tiki drink was created in 1978 at the Aviary bar of the Kuala Lumpur Hilton.

ingredients.ingredient: Dark aged Jamaican rum or Cruzan Black Strap rum

mix.how: Fill a mixing glass three-quarters with ice, and add all of the ingredients.
Shake until chilled for about 30 seconds.
Strain into a rocks glass over ice cubes or one large piece of ice, and add the garnish.

drinkName.name: Warm in the Winter
drinkName.about: This completely vegan cocktail takes Tiki to a dramatic level.

mix.how: Whip the gin, aquavit, Laura’s mix, juices, syrup, tincture and bitters, pour into a metal nautilus shell (or similarly shaped vessel), top with crushed ice, and garnish with 6 orchids, 6 pineapple fronds, 3 cheetah-print (or plain) straws and a flaming lime shell.
*Laura's mix: Combine 1 oz of banana liqueur, 1 oz of dry curaçao and 2 oz of cinnamon syrup.
**Flaming lime shell: Scoop out half a lime (or use what’s left after juicing), then add a splash of overproof rum and light the flame when serving.
